questions.question: Question 1: Which is the most common type of ovarian tumor?
questions.explanation: Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer?
questions.explanation:
BRCA 1 is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer. 805 
Sold by @itachibot 5–10% of malignant ovarian tumors are genetic. BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary 
breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. BRCA 1 is on chromosome 17q and BRCA 2 is on chromosome 13q. MSH2 and MLH1 gene mutation is seen in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). It 
is associated with malignancy of the colon, ovary, and endometrium.

questions.question: Question 3: Which among the following reduces the risk of developing ovarian cancers?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral tubectomy and hysterectomy reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. Some ovarian malignancies originate in the fallopian tubes as dysplastic lesions which later 
spread to the ovary (dropping down theory). Thus, bilateral tubectomy reduces the risk of ovarian 
malignancy. Risk factors for ovarian cancer: • Advancing age • Early menarche and late menopause • Talc exposure to the perineum • Family history of breast / ovarian cancer • Ovulation induction therapy by clomiphene citrate Protective factors against ovarian cancer: • Use of oral contraceptive pills • Multiparity • Breastfeeding • Anovulation.

questions.question: Question 4: Which among the following is the largest benign ovarian tumor?
questions.explanation:
Mucinous cystadenoma is the largest benign ovarian tumor. Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucoid-containing, thick-walled cyst. It is usually multilocular and 
lined by single columnar epithelium. It is the third most common epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has a 10% chance of becoming 
malignant. About 40% of dermoid cysts are found in conjunction with mucinous cystadenomas. 806 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is false regarding borderline ovarian tumors?

options.a: Mitotic figures are < 4/10 high power field
options.d: Serous type is more common than mucinous type

questions.explanation:
Stromal invasion is not seen in borderline ovarian tumors. Borderline tumors of the ovary (also called tumors of low malignant potential) are a 
heterogeneous group of lesions defined histologically by atypical epithelial proliferation without 
stromal invasion. The clinical progression of these tumors is distinct from ovarian carcinoma, so they are 
considered a distinct clinical entity. Features of borderline ovarian tumors: • No stromal invasion • Mitotic figures <4/10 high power field • Survival rate is 90% • Usually occurs between 35-55 years of age • Serous type is the most common, followed by mucinous type.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is false regarding ovarian cysts?

options.a: Cobweb appearance is seen on USG in haemorrhagic cyst
options.b: Theca lutein cyst regresses with a fall in hCG levels
options.c: Leutoma of pregnancy is associated with multiple pregnancy
options.d: Follicular cyst is a benign epithelial tumor

questions.explanation:
Follicular cyst is a physiological/functional cyst of the ovary. Physiological/functional cysts of the ovary: • Follicular cyst - Failure of rupture of the follicle during ovulation. • Theca lutein cyst - Stimulation of atretic follicles by abnormal HCG levels. It regresses when hCG 
levels fall. • Luteoma of pregnancy - Due to prolonged elevation of hCG, like in multiple pregnancies. 807 
Sold by @itachibot Hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually occur due to bleeding into the corpus luteum or other 
functional cysts at the time of ovulation. Hemorrhagic cysts are normal findings in ovulatory 
women, generally resolving within 8 weeks. Cobweb appearance on USG in a hemorrhagic cyst is shown below.

questions.question:
Question 7: Meigs' syndrome was suspected in a woman with right-sided pleural effusion, ascites, and an 
ovarian tumor. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Can be caused by ovarian fibroma
options.b: The tumor would be immobile with an irregular surface
options.c: Ascites and hydrothorax resolve after resection of the tumor
options.d: Pleural effusion is more common on the right side

questions.explanation:
In Meig's syndrome, a benign ovarian mass is likely to be seen. Irregular surface and immobility 
are features of malignant tumors. Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of: • Benign ovarian tumors • Ascites • Right-sided pleural effusion. The pleural effusions are usually right-sided, even though the left-sided and bilateral effusions are 
possible. Tumors causing Meigs' syndrome include ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, 
or thecoma. However, when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts 
(such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma), the condition is called Pseudo Meigs' syndrome. Resolution of ascites and pleural effusion is seen after the removal of the tumor. Management: • Repeated paracentesis for ascites. • Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy in young patients for preserving fertility 808 
Sold by @itachibot • Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO) in 
postmenopausal women. Note: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients may also have a combination of ascites, 
pleural effusion, and elevated serum levels of CA-125. This is known as Tjalma syndrome or 
pseudo-pseudo Meigs’ syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 8: An elderly woman who was found to have an ovarian mass underwent staging laparotomy. 
Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Psammoma bodies. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Psammoma bodies are a histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not 
denote malignancy. Psammoma bodies are seen in the following conditions: • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid • Papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium • Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary • Meningioma The image below shows Psammoma body.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 49-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen 
for the past 2 months. CT scan revealed a left-sided multiloculated adnexal mass and 
exploratory laparotomy showed small mucoid implants scattered in the peritoneal cavity. 
Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario and findings point to a diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei. It is 
associated with mucinous cystadenoma. Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare clinical entity characterized by diffuse intra-abdominal 
gelatinous and mucoid material on peritoneal surfaces. Spontaneous perforation of a mucinous 809 
Sold by @itachibot cystadenoma leads to implantation of low-grade malignant tumor cells in the peritoneum. However, the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei is carcinoma of the appendix. Diagnosis is by CT, MRI, and laparoscopy. Even after the removal of the ovarian tumor, these 
cells continue to secrete mucin. Recurrence rates are high.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe 
abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large 
cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads 
to this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the 
commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during 
puerperium. Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. 
This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. 
Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected. Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of 
the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most 
common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. 
It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. 
Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii. The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance. 810 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Staging laparotomy was performed in a teenage girl who presented with an adnexal mass. 
Histopathological examination showed the following. What is the diagnosis? 799 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor 
(endodermal sinus tumor). It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and 
sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually 
associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin. The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by 
tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of 
yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present. 811 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: What is the counterpart of seminoma in females?
questions.explanation:
The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. It is a germ cell tumor. It usually arises in young women or in children. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor 
diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ 
cell tumors. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in 
monitoring individuals or disease recurrence. Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good 
prognosis. Dysgerminoma was considered to be the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. 
Recent data indicates that in the past few decades, their incidence has reduced considerably. 
Immature teratomas are now the most common type of malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells 
resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes.

questions.question:
Question 13: The most common ovarian tumor in women less than 20 years of age is  
.
questions.explanation:
Germ cell tumors are the most common ovarian tumor in women aged less than 20 years. Epithelial tumours are the commonest tumours. It accounts for 80% of all ovarian malignant 
tumours.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following tumors show raised CA-125 levels?
questions.explanation:
Non-mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has elevated CA- 125 
levels. 812 
Sold by @itachibot CA-125 value > 35 U/ml is suggestive of epithelial ovarian cancer. Malignant conditions with raised CA 125 levels: • Ovarian epithelial carcinoma (most common cause) • Endometrial cancer • Pancreatic cancer • Colon cancer • Breast cancer • Lung cancer • Lymphoma Benign conditions with raised CA 125 levels: • Pregnancy • Pelvic inflammatory disease • Endometriosis • Uterine fibroid • Normally elevated in 1% females • Acute peritonitis

questions.question:
Question 15: A young woman with an adnexal mass is diagnosed with dysgerminoma. Which of the 
following tumor markers are likely to be elevated in her?
questions.explanation:
Lactate dehydrogenase is the tumor marker in dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a 
significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%). It is seen in young women with an average incidence of 20 years of age. It is the most common 
malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of 
all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (PALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and -hCG. 
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in 
monitoring individuals or disease recurrence. Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good 
prognosis.

questions.question:
Question 16: A post-menopausal woman is found to have an adnexal mass on evaluation. Above what risk 
of malignancy index (RMI) score is there a high risk of ovarian malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Risk of malignancy index (RMI) score of 200 or more indicates a high risk for ovarian cancer in a 
patient with an adnexal mass. Risk of malignancy index (RMI) = U x M x CA125 813 
Sold by @itachibot • U = Ultrasound score • The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular 
cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites, and bilateral lesions. • U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0) • U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1) • U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5). • M = Menopausal status • M= 1 (for pre-menopausal) • M= 3 (for post-menopausal) • CA-125 = Serum CA-125 level (in IU/ml) For any post-menopausal woman with an ovarian cyst of size >1cm, RMI should be calculated.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements is false regarding Brenner tumor?

options.b: It is associated with Meig's syndrome
options.c: Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen
options.d: It is not a malignant tumor

questions.explanation:
Brenner tumors are usually benign but rarely they can turn malignant. Brenner tumor (transitional cell tumor) is a benign, epithelial, unilateral tumor, resembling a 
fibroma. Histologically, Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen. Brenner tumor represent only 2-3% of all ovarian neoplasms, and <2% of these tumors are 
malignant. It is called Meigs' syndrome if the clinical picture is caused by an ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell 
tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma. Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of: • Benign ovarian tumor • Ascites • Right-sided pleural effusion. Pseudo Meigs' syndrome is when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and 
benign ovarian cysts such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma. The image given below shows Walthard cell rest. 814 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows coffee bean nuclei.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 31-year-old woman presenting with 12 weeks of amenorrhea and passage of vesicles per 
vagina is suspected to have a molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the left 
ovary appears as shown below. Which of the statements is not true regarding this condition?

options.a: Regresses spontaneously after removal of molar pregnancy
options.b: It is seen with clomiphene administration
options.d: Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor

questions.explanation:
The above scenario points to a diagnosis of theca lutein cysts in association with molar pregnancy. 
Theca lutein cysts are not associated with the use of oral contraceptives. Lutein cysts types : • Granulosa lutein cysts - They occur due to failure of regression of corpus luteum after 14 days of 
ovulation. • Theca lutein cysts - They are found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, 
and gonadotropin (hCG), or clomiphene therapy. 815 
Sold by @itachibot Theca lutein cysts occur due to the hyperstimulation of ovaries as a result of high hCG levels in 
molar pregnancies and other conditions. They are usually bilateral. These cysts usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2-4 months following the evacuation of a 
molar pregnancy. Sometimes they can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such 
instances, laparoscopic untwisting of the cyst has to be done.

questions.question:
Question 19: A woman noticed premature breast development in her 7-year-old daughter and brought her 
to the gynecology OPD. USG revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. The patient underwent 
laparotomy and the biopsy revealed Call-Exner bodies. Which of the following is true 
regarding this condition?

options.a: Most common malignant tumor of ovary
options.d: Inhibin A is elevated more than inhibin B

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumor. It is associated with 
carcinoma endometrium. Granulosa cell tumors cells are estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors. It is seen in 80% of women 
over 40 years and 5% of pre-pubertal girls. Precocious puberty is seen due to excess secretion of 
estrogen. It is a low-grade malignancy. It is almost always unilateral. Tumor marker inhibin B is frequently 
elevated more than inhibin A. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice. On histopathology, it has characteristic Call-Exner bodies. It appears as a rosette arrangement of 
cells around an eosinophilic fluid space, as shown below.

questions.question:
Question 20: 802 
Sold by @itachibot Which among the following high-risk patients are suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy?

options.b: History of ovarian cancer in a 2nd-degree relative
options.c: Abnormal ovary in reproductive age group woman
options.d: One ovary removed for benign neoplasm

questions.explanation:
Prophylactic oophorectomy is indicated if one ovary has already been removed for benign 
neoplasm. Candidates suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy: • Nulliparous aged > 45 years 816 
Sold by @itachibot • Any age with a history of ovarian, endometrial, or colon cancer in a 1st-degree relative • Grossly abnormal ovary in the premenopausal age group • One ovary removed for benign neoplasm • Previous history of breast carcinoma • Radiation-induced menopause

questions.question:
Question 21: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and 
significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and 
liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
questions.explanation:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or 
regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement. Grading of ovarian cancer: • Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less 
likely to spread or recur. • Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. • Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared to 
normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman is diagnosed with early-stage ovarian cancer. Which surgery 
should be done in her case?
questions.explanation:
Unilateral oophorectomy is preferred in a young woman who has not completed her family in case 
of early-stage disease.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following ovarian tumors is the most radiosensitive?
questions.explanation:
Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. They are highly susceptible 
to radiotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman on HRT presented with abdominal pain for the past 6 
months. On examination, a non-tender, right adnexal mass was palpable. USG showed a 3 x 3 
cm smooth ovarian cyst. What is the next best step in her case?

options.a: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
options.b: Confirmation of USG findings by CT scan
options.c: Exploratory laparotomy for evaluation of cyst
options.d: CA- 125 level estimation; if normal, advise regular follow-up

questions.explanation:
CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for 
post-menopausal ovarian cysts. Management includes the following: • Calculation of Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) = U x M x Ca-125, where • U = ultrasound score • M = menopausal status 817 
Sold by @itachibot • Ca 125 = serum levels • Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200. Option B - CT scan is not recommended for initial evaluation. It is done only for further 
evaluation and when RMI > 200.

questions.question:
Question 25: Examination of a resected specimen of an ovarian mass reveals signet ring cells are seen as 
shown below. Which of the following conditions is this associated with?
questions.explanation:
Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor. A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy that metastasized from a primary site, most 
commonly from the stomach (70%). Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly 
invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites. The route of spread may be: • Lymphatic • Hematogenous • Transcoelomic They are usually bilateral and have a smooth surface with a waxy consistency. They retain the 
shape of a normal ovary. Given below are the images of the Krukenberg tumor's gross appearance and histological 
appearance with signet ring cells: 818 
Sold by @itachibot 819 
Sold by @itachibot Vulval & Vaginal Malignancy
